Catrina is one of the most recognized symbols of the Day of the Dead (Día de los Muertos) in Mexico. This elegant skeleton, dressed in fancy clothes and a large, feathered hat, has an intriguing history that reflects Mexico's complex relationship
with life and death, as well as social and political issues. The figure of La Catrina was created in the early 20th century by Mexican artist José Guadalupe Posada. He was a political satirist who used his artwork to criticize the rich and powerful. His depiction of the skeleton, originally called "La Calavera Garbancera," was a critique of Mexicans who, at the time, aspired to adopt European fashion and traditions, abandoning their own indigenous roots.
